data.text: Contents
Introduction

The Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE) is comprised of a range of diverse services which are committed to providing high quality patient centred care in all areas that we serve. Staff are our most important resource and therefore the facilitation of highly competent, patient focused, experienced and resourceful staff is a key requirement of achieving this high quality service.

Clinical supervision is not a new concept and has been recommended as highly important within ongoing NHS policy in documents such as the NHS Pan and Darzi next stage review (2008) and also in the Care Quality Commission (CQC) report “supporting effective clinical supervision” (2013).
Skills for care (2017) define ‘supervision' as an ‘'accountable process which supports, assures and develops the knowledge skills and values of an individual group or team''.

The aim of Clinical supervision is to promote professional development by fostering an open culture of learning from both positive and negative events and replicating best practice. Clinical supervision in the workplace is a way of using reflective practice and experiences as part of continuing professional development, and improving care for patients. It achieves this through focussed support, reflection and continued professional development.

The Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC 2015) supports the establishment of clinical supervision as an important part of clinical governance and in the interests of maintaining and improving standards of patient and service user care. The revised code states that nurses should share their skills, knowledge and experience for the benefit of people receiving care and for their colleagues.

Guidance from the Care Quality Commission advises that Clinical Supervision: ‘Can help staff to manage the personal and professional demands created by the nature of their work. This is particularly important for those who have complex and challenging needs – clinical supervision provides an environment in which they can explore their own personal and emotional reactions to their work.  It can allow the member of staff to reflect on and challenge their own practice in a safe confidential manner' CQC (2013)
Outcome 14c refers to clinical supervision:

Supervisory or peer support arrangements are in place, monitored and reviewed, for all staff involved in delivering care, treatment and support, in line with relevant national guidance from professional bodies.

A support structure is in place for supervision which includes one to one sessions or group meetings. They are undertaken at a time and frequency agreed between the line manager or facilitator and the staff member, and they are recorded. (CQC 2013)

The Health Care Professions Council standard of proficiency also recognises the importance of clinical supervision alongside other forms of Continuing Professional Development, as do other specific regulatory bodies of the Allied
Health professions e.g. College of Occupational Therapists and Physiotherapy (HCPC 201).
Scope
This policy has been developed to:

Ensure all healthcare professionals (Clinical Staff) both registered and unregistered are aware of the Trust's commitment to ensure Clinical Supervision is accessible for all staff employed in a clinical capacity in all Care Groups and Divisions / Services within the Trust.
Provide guidance by describing the requirements and expectations of clinical supervision for all health care professionals who are employed by Southend University Hospital Trust.

Outline the importance of clinical supervision and the role it plays in the development of all health care professionals. This is in accordance with regulations set out by professional regulatory bodies and their specific requirements and codes of conduct.

Establish clear processes for clinical supervision to enhance consumer safety and protection for the patient by ensuring that all care provided is delivered by skilled safe and knowledgeable practitioners

Maintain the quality of clinical supervision provided to staff by working to a common set of principles and standards which are supported by a variety of modes of delivery in accordance with trust requirements.

Improve the quality of care by the use of supervision techniques, which allow individuals to assess their own performance and make any necessary changes required to improve poor practice and enabling professional development.
Enable staff to share good practice and support the development of clinical expertise and innovation in practice.
Definitions

table_items.text: A formal process of professional support and learning that enables individual practitioners to develop knowledge and competence be responsible for their own practice and patient protection and safety of care in a wide range of situations.
Healthcare professional who engages in clinical supervision activity.
A person who facilitates a clinical supervision session. Do not give opinions of solutions allow the group or person to find their own solutions through active questioning techniques.
The structured sharing of a topic from clinical practice and discussions between supervisor and supervisee.
Sharing of a topic from clinical practice between supervisor and more than one supervisee, from the same or different health care professions.

All issues discussed will be in confidence, unless there is anything disclosed that affects the wellbeing of the supervisee and their professional practice or is detrimental to a patients welfare, the professional team, or the organisation as a whole

The supervisee is required to maintain a history of activity by the recording of clinical supervision activity in documents (electronic or paper) such as clinical supervision activity logs Appendices 5,6,7,& 8
All healthcare professionals should be aware of their signed personal service agreement and follow the guidelines of this policy at all clinical supervision sessions

Due regard for advancing equality involves: Removing or minimising disadvantages suffered by people due to their protected characteristics. Taking steps to meet the needs of people from protected groups where these are different from the needs of other people. Encouraging people from protected groups to participate in public life or in other activities where their participation is disproportionately low.

The Care Act 2014 (Section 42) requires that each local authority must make enquiries, or cause others to do so, if it believes an adult is experiencing, or is at risk of, abuse or neglect. An enquiry should establish whether any action needs to be taken to prevent or stop abuse or neglect, and if so, by whom.

data.text: Roles and Responsibilities

Deputy Directors of Nursing and ADoN meetings – Endorse the policy ensuring that structures and opportunities are in place to access Clinical Supervision. To monitor compliance with the policy within clinical areas.
The Managing Director and Trust Board

Has a legal responsibility for Trust policies and for ensuring that they are carried out effectively. The Trust is fully committed to this policy and supporting the staff groups identified in the policy to access clinical supervision.
Duties of Medical Director / Allied Health Professional Lead
A structure exists to ensure all professional registered staff are in receipt of regular clinical supervision and other support in accordance with their registered council.
Director of Nursing
Staff are in receipt of regular Clinical supervision which meets the needs of the area and its staff
Duties of Matron

An annual audit is undertaken and reported to ascertain the robustness and adequacy of the clinical supervision systems and structures in place. There is an expectation that all leads, Heads of nursing and matrons will champion and facilitate staff members in accessing clinical supervision if required.
Duties of Line manager/Ward manager/team leaders
Ensuring that all members within the team(s) including themselves have access to clinical supervision with a supervisor who has the expertise and experience to provide guidance and support.
4.6.1 Determining the most appropriate method (s) of ensuring that all clinical staff have access to clinical supervision i.e. individual, group/team or peer supervision.
4.6.2 Ensuring staff have access to the clinical supervision charter (see appendix 4).

4.6.3 Clearly understand their role and responsibilities in regard to providing access and facilitation to clinical supervision. Making the time available on e-roster for staff clinical supervision sessions, when required.
4.6.4 Ensuring the privacy of the environment in which the supervision will take place.
4.6.5 Reviewing the arrangements for clinical supervision on a regular basis.
4.6.6 Ensuring that key staff are appropriately trained to act as a clinical supervisor and that all staff have the knowledge to be able to participate and benefit from clinical supervision.
4.6.7 Ensuring that job descriptions of all healthcare professionals/ practitioners include a statement regarding the responsibilities of the individual in respect of clinical supervision.
4.6.8 Collecting data regarding improvements, staff/ service user feedback and actions taken as a result of clinical supervision within their teams.
Responsibilities of Supervisor for either one to one or group supervision Set up one to one or group membership session times and dates.
4.7.1 Discuss and agree a contract and ground rules with person/group (Appendix 5).
4.7.2 Prepare before the session.
4.7.3 Use effective question techniques during the session (Appendix 2).
4.7.4 Follow the flowchart guidance for Clinical Supervision (Appendix 1).
4.7.5 Ensure effective timekeeping.
4.7.6 Complete paperwork after session (Appendices 5,6,7,8).
Responsibilities of Participant / Supervisee
Accessing clinical supervision sessions as required. Ensuring they are supported by an experienced supervisor to achieve this.
4.8.1 Drawing up a written supervision agreement with their supervisor/ following guidelines outlined within this policy (Appendix 3).
4.8.2 Attend training on clinical supervision.
4.8.3 Discuss and agree the contract with your facilitator and/or group.
4.8.4 Participate during the session.
4.8.5 Reflect after the session.
4.8.6 Carry out identified actions from the clinical supervision session.
Main procedural document points

The minimum requirement for Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is for staff to engage with clinical supervision as required that is either in partnership with their line manager or on self-referral
Clinical supervision modes of delivery

There are several modes of delivery and healthcare staff may access a variety of these in practice. The mode of delivery will be determined by the service within which they are employed and organisational capacity and in accordance with professional requirements as set out by regulatory bodies; e.g. Psychologists, Medical staff Allied Nursing and Health Care Professionals, Pharmacy, Physiotherapists, Occupational Therapists, Midwives and Health Visitors.
The Trust acknowledges that different professional groups will undertake clinical supervision in various forms and will also have different frequency requirements
All health care professionals must be afforded protected time to undertake clinical supervision
The modes of delivery are:
One to one supervision: this type of clinical supervision usually takes place between two members of the same staff group with the supervisor being senior to the supervisee.

Peer Group Supervision: takes place within a small group setting, with the same grade staff who have equal experience and share the supervision session equally. The supervisor must have the expertise to guide and support the supervisees.

Multidisciplinary Group Supervision: This model of clinical supervision takes place between a facilitator and a group. The facilitator does not have a line management responsibility with the group and the supervisees will be from different disciplines.
Network Supervision: is between professionals and could involve a Specialist topic: An example of this is where professionals from different trusts link to share expertise.
Types and role of supervision in practice

Other methods of supervision co-exist to support each individual throughout their career as a health professional. Effective clinical supervision will incorporate elements of all these aspects, providing a powerful toolkit for personal and professional development. If a balance between models of supervision is not achieved, for example the managerial function is stressed at the expense of others then supervision becomes a management tool that can stifle creativity and innovation. Likewise if the supportive role dominates it could prevent decisions or actions being achieved.
Types and role of supervision in practice

Other methods of supervision co-exist to support each individual throughout their career as a health professional. Effective clinical supervision will incorporate elements of all these aspects, providing a powerful toolkit for personal and professional development. If a balance between models of supervision is not achieved, for example the managerial function is stressed at the expense of others then supervision becomes a management tool that can stifle creativity and innovation. Likewise if the supportive role dominates it could prevent decisions or actions being achieved.
Managerial supervision
This form of supervision focuses on service development, caseload.

Management and day to day issues of regarding team working, service delivery, environment and workplace. This type of supervision is delivered by the supervisee's line manager and must be provided on a consistent basis.
Professional supervision

Professional supervision supports safe and effective service delivery through an application of ethical codes and professional standards. It should allow for reflection on current professional issues, developments and changes relevant to any professional group. An example of this is the trust preceptorship programme that allows newly qualified staff nurses to access shared learning to develop their professional skills.
Educational Supervision

Educational supervision aims to ensure best practice and encourages and challenges the supervisee to continually improve, extend and develop their practice and skills. It will provide the supervisee with the knowledge to ensure their practice is safe and of a high quality. This aspect of supervision forms an important part of the supervisee's appraisal plan by increasing expertise and innovation and developing their scope of practice.
Informal supervision

Gardner et al (2010) describe superficial supervision whereby staff may not engage in reflective supervision because they perceive that their difficulties have been resolved through informal or corridor conversations with their colleagues. Clearly et al (2010) recognise that these conversations support nurses in daily care management providing ongoing opportunities to discuss problematic situations that can help to contain anxieties, reduce the feeling of isolation and relieve stress. Gardner et al acknowledged the value of such an informal approach, however they concluded that some issues should be followed up within formal supervision activity as informal interactions are unstructured and do not allow for deep understanding or reflection.
What is the difference between management supervision and clinical supervision?

The key difference is that the Manager leads management supervision. In clinical supervision, the Supervisee leads and sets the agenda. Generally, clinical supervision is seen as complimentary to but separate from, managerial supervision, which is about monitoring and appraising staff performance. However, both should be used to obtain information on development to support and feed into the appraisal process and support in your practice and the services where you are employed.

table_items.text: Being self-driven and self-owned by participants
Setting priorities / objectives for the team in line with organisational objectives
Listening and being heard, affirming inclusive and being mutually supportive for all
Supports staff with managing sickness and absence
Being open to questions and receptive to challenges in a constructive way
Plans and updates annual leave / time owing to ensure staffing levels
Exploring the relationship between actions and feelings
Providing a safe place to explore and share the burdens of work
Facilitating a structured framework for reflective thinking

data.text: Clinical supervision and staff responsibility in the assessment and
management of risk

The assessment and management of risk is core to the role of clinicians in Contemporary health services. While it is unrealistic to expect that all adverse incidents can be prevented, the risk for each individual can still be identified, managed and possibly avoided. The Risk Management Policy and Procedure MSEPO-21092 make it clear that issues regarding clinical risk assessment must be reviewed in clinical supervision. The policy states that it is the supervisee's responsibility to regularly discuss risk assessments, particularly those of high risk cases with their supervisor.

Ultimately the purpose of clinical supervision is to safeguard the wellbeing of the client and assist with the development of the supervisee, thus making clinical supervision an important contribution to the way we manage clinical risk (Banks et al 2012, Tingle 1995) by adopting proactive patient management strategies and reflecting on skills, the risk of adverse events occurring will be reduced.

Walker and Clark (1999) suggest that clinical supervision can offer compassionate risk management by addressing early warning signs that can herald a more serious risk to patients. Many clinicians receive supervision for cases that are seen as particularly challenging, stuck or risky. While it is important to prioritise such cases, supervisors should be aware of the need to focus on cases that appear more straightforward as it is possible to miss something that supervision can appropriately address.

Ladany 2004 (cited in Turpin and Wheeler 2007) has reported the failure of some therapists to disclose ongoing difficulties within their clinical work in supervision, which might reflect poorly on their own competence and performance as therapists. Supervisors must ensure that consideration is given to the strengths and weakness of the assessment carried out and the documentation and care planning around risk assessment if appropriate. Some Acceptable Clinical Supervision Models
Appraisal must identify objectives for professional ongoing clinical supervision.
Revalidation reflective discussion can be considered clinical supervision.

Foundation level 1:1 an initial supervision session must be obtained by all clinical staff to ensure a basic understanding of the process, skills and knowledge required. This can be used to develop a plan of action for

ongoing reflection. Following this session clinical supervision training will be provided as required through Learning and Development which will include practical sessions to explore. This could also be facilitated by e learning or journal articles.
Reflective 1:1 supervision will involve a clinical facilitator of your choice and a framework of your choice.

Professional Supervision 1:1 supervision with an experienced practitioner in order to reflect on caseload management and treatment plans and receive coaching to improve practice and professional development Solution Focused Group

supervision can be obtained using the Solution-Focused Model for Reflecting Teams by Norman (2003) & O'Connell (2005). An inclusive approach should be adopted when developing group sessions including all those involved in the patient pathway including various disciplines and organisations where appropriate. E.g. porters, housekeepers.

Case management supervision - when care plan goals are not met this will trigger the need to discuss the case of the patient/service user with a more experienced practitioner in order to reflect on clinical practice and treatment options in order to meet the clinical and patient goals.

Solution focused reflecting team - when a group of participants (max 8) agree to meet regularly (every 3 months) to engage in clinical supervision facilitated by someone not directly line managing any participant. (Appendix

Adult safe guarding supervision – As per the Policy for the Safeguarding of Adults Policy MSEPO-20235 “It is recognised that staff involved in the management of an adult safeguarding enquiry case may find the experience stressful and distressing or difficult to manage. Staff who are in need of immediate support should contact the following members of staff for immediate support:
Ward/Department Manager
Division Matron
Clinical Site Manager out of hours
Adult Safeguarding Team

In addition to the immediate support offered to staff outlined in the above procedures, staff have access to existing staff support services available via Occupational Health. Reference should also be made to the MSE Trust's Stress Management Policy MSEPO-21118

All staff involved in a Section 42 Enquiry are offered clinical supervision by the Adult Safeguarding Team. Staff can access this support by contacting the Adult Safeguarding Team. Any confidentiality concerns can be discussed as part of the supervision contract.

Although staff involved in a Section 42 Enquiry: are routinely offered safeguarding clinical supervision, any staff involved with the safeguarding of an adult at risk can request supervision from the Adult Safeguarding Team.

All members of the Adult Safeguarding Team are routinely offered safeguarding supervision at least every 3 months or more frequently on request. The Adult Safeguarding Manager is responsible for keeping records of supervision using the agreed forms (Appendix 4).
Please see Adult Safeguarding Training strategy Policy MSEPO-20240

It is recognised that staff can access different levels of support depending on need. For this reason staff must have access to the contact details for the Adult safeguarding Team so that informal or formal support can be obtained.
This policy recognises adult safeguarding supervision as part of the 4 annual sessions required to meet the CQC criteria for clinical supervision.
Children and young person safeguarding supervision
(Working Together to Safeguard Children, HM Government 2018). Defines it as

“An accountable process which supports assures and develops the knowledge, skills and values of an individual, group or team. The purpose is to improve the quality of their work in order to achieve agreed outcomes”
The Trust has outlined the following standard for staff working with children and young people to adhere to and will count towards their 4 clinical supervision sessions annually.

“As a minimum, case holding staff will receive Safeguarding Children supervision at least every three months but more frequently if required. For key clinical groups inclusive of Neonatal, Children's Services and Paediatric Emergency Department, Safeguarding supervision will be offered at a minimum of four times per year. It is expected that staff working within these groups will attend Safeguarding supervision no less than two times per year but more frequently if Required” Child Safeguarding” Supervision Policy MSEPO-19011

Non-Medical Prescriber– Ongoing Professional Development is an important part of maintaining competence and confidence in Non-Medical prescribing. The Trust runs 4 Non-Medical prescribing meetings per year and mandates that practitioners attend a minimum of 2 meetings. A clinical forum forms part of this meeting and therefore these meetings form part of the practitioner's clinical supervision requirement.
Confidentiality

All discussions will be treated as confidential and not disclosed without prior permission. However, staff must be aware that in honouring confidentiality they have a duty to report issues of professional misconduct or safeguarding concerns and that these concerns must be reported immediately to the appropriate manager.

Where issues or concerns about the practice or welfare of the participant are identified as part of the supervisory process the facilitator will inform the participant that the line manager will be informed and will act accordingly.
Record keeping

Clinical supervision must be recorded to ensure that discussions and agreed actions can be referred back-to by both parties as part of an ongoing process of monitoring, development and support for the supervisees practice

There is no stipulated timeframe to keep clinical supervision records as they are a personal record of development. It is therefore recommended that the records are maintained in line with the standards of the individual's profession to allow for reflection if required at a later date e.g. Registered nurses would maintain their reflections for a period of 3 years in accordance with Revalidation guidelines.
Ground rules must be agreed and understood ideally as part of the supervision contract.
Goals or aims of the session to be discussed and documented. Appendix One or Two depending on group or one to one session.
A written record of the supervision sessions with agreed action plan will be completed and kept securely and sent to all participants by the facilitator.
A (register) record will be kept of the date, time and attendees of each clinical supervision session.
Line managers will keep records of clinical supervision attendance within their teams for audit purposes via the Trust site specific -electronic staff rostering systems.
Training requirements

All staff are responsible for maintaining their own professional competence, according to their own professional accountability. Staff must maintain a portfolio of clinical practice demonstrating evidence of their ongoing competence to practice. This includes evidence of attendance at clinical supervision sessions.

It is the responsibility of Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust to ensure that training is provided to equip participants and facilitators with an understanding of the supervision process and facilitators with the necessary competencies to provide effective clinical supervision. The Learning and Development Team will ensure there is access to the necessary education and training to provide initial training for new staff and to allow existing staff to update skills as identified as necessary.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.
Audit of clinical supervision

Clinical Supervision compliance and quality will be monitored within the Quality Assessment Tool and in the annual audit programme. Attendees will evaluate clinical supervision sessions including learning and patient outcomes. This will be evaluated annually through the use of questionnaires.

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group/Committ ee/forum which will receive the findings/monito ring report
Committee/indiv idual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
6 monthly check on e- roster to confirm compliance with protected time out

data.text: Where monitoring identifies any shortfall in compliance the group responsible for the Policy (as identified on the policy cover) shall be responsible for developing and monitoring any action plans to ensure future compliance
Compliance in relation to Clinical Supervision will be monitored on a monthly basis The Trust Learning Management System will be used to record and evidence clinical supervision.
The data generated will monitor the compliance, training implementation and quality of clinical supervision for all healthcare staff.
Team managers are responsible for monitoring compliance within their clinical area.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE Senior Nursing Team MSE, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local MSE Senior Nursing Team policies. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the MSE Senior Nursing Team of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Preliminary equality analysis
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 7)

Appendix 1: Flow chart guidance for clinical supervision
FLOW CHART GUIDANCE FOR CLINICAL SUPERVISION
PREPARATION

Prepare for the meeting in advance, protected time, suitable location, free from interruptions, prepare paperwork required, have you got a copy of the last record for review and discussion (if applicable)
ORGANISATION

Safeguarding: Best practice acknowledges that all Nursing and Allied Health Professionals should be aware of the principles / ground rules outlined within a Clinical Supervision agreement at every Clinical Supervision contact.
ACTIONS
Have any actions, training or further development needs been identified / agreed by all participant/s?
Agree the entries into the activity log, who will complete each action? and record this Complete activity logs
RECORDING SUPERVISION NOTES
In the interest of all participants, supervision notes should be promptly & properly recorded. All participants should be made aware of how these may accessed or retain a copy as a personal record
Appendix 2: Clinical supervision, what can we talk about?
Clinical Supervision, What can we talk about?

Participants in clinical supervision describe events/ experiences from their practice which is pertinent to them as an individual or a topic affecting / chosen by the group. Example: reviewing a critical incident / debrief or a topic to explore what happened, share best interest principles or research evidence and learn from this.

Appendix 3: Clinical supervision agreement
Clinical Supervision Agreement
Supervisee and Supervisor will agree to the following
That we will meet…………………………………………………… as agreed by the service (this will differ for different services in the trust so must be agreed by the line manager)
Sessions will be supported and recorded in line with trust policy.
Privacy must be ensured with no interruptions.

The session will enable the supervisee and supervisor to discuss, explore and reflect on issues affecting practice, to support the development of personal and professional knowledge in order to sustain and develop high quality practice.
The content of the clinical supervision session will include: Reviewing and reflecting on clinical practice
Discussing current issues, concerns and risk assessments
Discussing issues related to professional development
Agreeing upon actions where identified and ensuring that the actions are completed. We will work together to develop clinical supervision and be open and honest on how we give feedback to each other.

We will ensure we work in the boundaries of confidentiality in relation to clinical supervision and will not include anything that is illegal or contravenes the code of professional conduct or trust policy.
We agree to commit to clinical supervision on the dates agreed. If the session is cancelled it will be the responsibility of the person who cancels to rearrange the session.

If the supervisory partnership becomes ineffective or difficulties arise either supervisee or supervisor can, following discussion terminate the agreement. If this occurs the supervisee must seek support from their line manager to identify a new supervisor
As supervisee I agree to:
To identify and action any learning or development needs
To identify practice issues for discussion and be open to feedback regarding possible interventions and solutions
To take responsibility for any actions or outcomes following the clinical supervision session
Be responsible for making effective use of my time, by preparing for the session and knowing my agenda
As supervisor I agree to:
Provide an environment that allows the supervisee to explore, clarify thinking and share experiences.
Give clear feedback, offering support and guidance regarding the situations the supervisees talks about
Provide advice, information and sign posting to allow the supervisee to reflect and develop their professional practice
Always consider our Trust Values and Compassion in Practice (6c's)
Appendix 4: Clinical supervision charter
Clinical Supervision Charter

The Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (MSE) is committed to providing all Nursing and Allied Healthcare practitioners with high quality support and an opportunity to discuss and reflect on their practice. This aims to promote best practice principles such as evidence based practice, shared learning, develop experience and assure competence.
While working within the services of the MSE NHS Foundation Trust:
You have the right to regular clinical supervision with a supervisor with
relevant experience and expertise, including specialist supervision in specific situations

You have the responsibility to ensure you have had the appropriate training and are competent to complete any interventions within your clinical area You will have clinical supervision at a minimum of four times a year, one session per quarter, for a minimum of one hour as per trust policy. This will differ in your specific directorate / service so you must liaise with your line manager to ensure you meet the requirements for the service where you are employed.

You have the right to talk to your line manager about your clinical supervision and it is the responsibility of your line manager to confirm your identified clinical supervisor with the relevant experience and expertise.
You have the right to be involved in choosing your supervisor and to request a change of supervisor.
You have the right to request that clinical supervision takes place in a quiet private area with no interruptions.
You have the right to negotiate a contract between yourself and your supervisor
An accessible record of the date and time of clinical supervision sessions must be retained for audit purposes.
You have the right to negotiate the recording of and access to other information as described in the confidentiality section of the clinical supervision policy.
Both the supervisor and supervisee have the right and the responsibility to report any concerns about the quality and frequency of clinical supervision to the appropriate line manager.
Appendix 5: Example: Register / agreement / ground rules for clinical supervision

table_items.text: Example: Register / Agreement / Ground Rules for Clinical Supervision Why? Establishing ground rules for all Clinical Supervision activity helps to promote the sharing of experiences, disseminates best practice, ensures participants feel safe, valued and establishes trust. Acknowledging these ground rules and keeping a copy on view enables all participants to remain mindful of the rules of clinical supervision and also aids the group dynamic to function to in a healthy manner

We agree to: Respect Confidentiality and abide by the principles Respect our colleagues and each other's opinions Listen and acknowledge each other effectively Constructively challenge Involve all in discussion and do-not dominate Allow others to own their experience Be responsible and consider own health & well-being and also participant/s Manage time effectively
Brief description of issue discussed / complete activity log

All staff across MSE in regard to Clinical supervision

a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
Deputy Director Of Nursing Theatres and Anaesthetics
